sen.j: 大炊御門 麗子（おおいのみかど れいし、藤原 麗子（ふじわら の れいし）、中宮 麗子、元暦2年／文治元年（1185年） - 寛元元年9月18日 (旧暦)（1243年11月1日））は、鎌倉時代の土御門天皇の中宮。
sen.e: Reishi OINOMIKADO, FUJIWARA no Reishi, Empress Reishi (1185-November 1, 1243) was a chugu of Emperor Tsuchimikado in the Kamakura period.
Reishi OINOMIKADO, FUJIWARA no Reishi, Empress Reishi (1185-November 1, 1243) was a chugu of Emperor Tsuchimikado during the Kamakura period.
Reishi OINOMIKADO (also known as FUJIWARA no Reishi and Empress Reishi, 1185 - November 8, 1243) was a chugu of Emperor Tsuchimikado during the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 女院号は陰明門院（おんめいもんいん）。
sen.e: Her nyoingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) was Onmeimonin.
Her nyoingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) was Onmeimonin.
Her nyoingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) was Onmeimonin.

sen.j: 太政大臣藤原頼実の女。
sen.e: She was a daughter of Grand Minister, FUJIWARA no Yorizane.
She was the daughter of Grand Minister, FUJIWARA no Yorizane.
She was the daughter of Grand Minister, FUJIWARA no Yorizane.

sen.j: 生母は左京大夫藤原定隆の女、藤原隆子。
sen.e: Her birth mother was a daughter of Sakyo no daibu (Master of the Eastern Capital Offices), FUJIWRA no Sadataka, FUJIWARA no Takako.
Her birth mother was the daughter of Sakyo no daibu (Master of the Eastern Capital Offices), FUJIWARA no Sadataka, FUJIWARA no Takako.
Her birth mother was the daughter of Sakyo no daibu (Master of the Eastern Capital Offices), FUJIWARA no Sadataka, FUJIWARA no Takako.

sen.j: 建久9年（1198年）、土御門天皇の大嘗祭の際に女御代を務めた。
sen.e: In 1198, she served as nyogo-dai (court lady who acted for nyogo) in Daijo-sai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) of Emperor Tsuchimikado.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In 1198, she served as nyogo-dai (court lady who acted for nyogo) in theDaijo-sai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) for Emperor Tsuchimikado.
In 1198, she served as nyogo-dai (court lady who acted for nyogo) in the Daijo-sai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) for Emperor Tsuchimikado.

sen.j: 元久2年（1205年）4月、21歳で10歳年下の土御門天皇のもとに入内して女御宣下を受け、同年7月に中宮に冊立される。
sen.e: In April 1205, she entered into court of Emperor Tsuchimikado who was ten years younger than her, and was given the title of nyogo; she was formally installed to chugu in July in the same year.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In April 1205, she entered into the court of Emperor Tsuchimikado who was ten years younger than her, and was given the title of nyogo; she was formally installed as chugu in July during the same year.

In April 1205, she entered into the court of Emperor Tsuchimikado who was ten years younger than her at the age of 21, and was given the title of nyogo; she was formally installed as chugu in July during the same year.

sen.j: しかし麗子は子を産むこともないまま、承元4年（1210年）3月に院号宣下を受けた。
sen.e: Reishi never had a child with the emperor, and was given the title of ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) in March 1210.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Reishi never had a child with the emperor, and was given the title of ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) in March 1210.
Reishi never had a child with the emperor, and was given the title of ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) in April 1210.

sen.j: 同年11月には土御門天皇が異母弟の守成親王（順徳天皇）に譲位している。
sen.e: In November in 1210, the Emperor Tsuchimikado abdicated his throne to his younger brother with a different mother, Imperial Prince Morinari (Emperor Juntoku).
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In November in 1210, the Emperor Tsuchimikado abdicated his throne to his younger step brother who had a different mother, Imperial Prince Morinari (Emperor Juntoku).
In November in 1210, the Emperor Tsuchimikado abdicated his throne to his younger step brother who had a different mother, Imperial Prince Morinari (Emperor Juntoku).

sen.j: 承久3年（1221年）1月に麗子は出家し、法号を清浄妙と称する。
sen.e: In January 1221, Reishi became a priest, and was referred to herself as Shojomyo as hogo (Buddhist name).
In January 1221, Reishi became a priest, and referred to herself as Shojomyo as hogo (Buddhist name).
In February 1221, Reishi became a priest, and referred to herself as Shojomyo as hogo (Buddhist name).

sen.j: 同年5月には承久の乱が勃発した。
sen.e: In May 1221, Jokyu Disturbance occurred.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In May 1221, the Jokyu Disturbance occurred.
In May 1221, the Jokyu Disturbance occurred.

sen.j: 乱の終結後、土御門上皇は乱に直接関与していなかったにもかかわらず、父後鳥羽天皇の隠岐国への配流が決定すると自ら望んで土佐国に配流されたが、麗子は同行せず京に留まった。
sen.e: After the Jokyu Disturbance was over, the retired Emperor Tsuchimikado decided to be exiled to Tosa Province on his own will, though he was not directly involved with the disturbance, when his father, Emperor Gotoba was determined to be exiled to Oki Province; Reishi remained to stay in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: After the Jokyu Disturbance was over, the retired Emperor Tsuchimikado decided to willingly be exiled to Tosa Province, even though he was not directly involved in the disturbance, when his father, Emperor Gotoba was determined to be exiled to Oki Province; Reishi remained in Kyoto.

After the Jokyu Disturbance was over, the Retired Emperor Tsuchimikado decided to willingly be exiled to Tosa Province, even though he was not directly involved in the disturbance, when his father, Emperor Gotoba was determined to be exiled to Oki Province; Reishi remained in Kyoto.

sen.j: 寛喜3年（1231年）、土御門上皇が配流先の阿波国で崩御すると、麗子は自身の封戸、年官、年爵を辞して隠遁し、寛元元年（1243年）、59歳で崩御した。
sen.e: When the retired Emperor Tsuchimikado passed away in Awa Province where he was exiled in 1231, Reishi abdicated fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrines and temples), nenkan (a right granted as a stipend to members of the Imperial family (including the emperor), consorts of the emperor, some Court nobles, and so forth to nominate a person for a certain government post conferred to them on the occasion of the annual installation of them as government officials), nenshaku (a right granted as a stipend to a retired emperor, the mother of the Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager, the Empress, and so forth to nominate a person for a certain rank conferred to them on the occasion of the annual conferment of a rank to them) and retired; she passed away at the age of fifty nine years old.

When retired Emperor Tsuchimikado passed away in Awa Province, where he was exiled in 1231, Reishi abdicated fuko (a vassal household allotted to a courtier, shrines and temples), nenkan (a right granted as a stipend to members of the Imperial family - including the emperor, consorts of the emperor, some Court nobles, and so forth to nominate a person for a certain government post conferred to them on the occasion of annually installing them as government officials), nenshaku (a right granted as a stipend to a retired emperor, the mother of the Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager, the Empress, etc., to nominate a person for a certain rank conferred to them on the occasion of the annual conferment of a rank) and retired; she passed away at the age of fifty nine years old.

When Retired Emperor Tsuchimikado passed away in Awa Province, where he was exiled in 1231, Reishi abdicated fuko (a vassal household allotted to a courtier, shrines and temples), nenkan (a right granted as a stipend to members of the Imperial Family - including the emperor, consorts of the emperor, some Court nobles, and so forth to nominate a person for a certain government post conferred to them on the occasion of annually installing them as government officials), nenshaku (a right granted as a stipend to a retired emperor, the mother of the Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager, the Empress, etc., to nominate a person for a certain rank conferred to them on the occasion of the annual conferment of a rank) and retired; she passed away at the age of fifty nine years old in 1243.
